rule-metadata.name: Package Html
rule-metadata.description: Checks that a package.html file exists for each package. More specifically, checks that each java file has a package.html sibling.

property-metadata.name: fileExtensions
property-metadata.description: file type extension to identify java files. Setting this property is typically only required if your java source files are preprocessed and the original files do not have the extension .java

rule-metadata.name: Method Javadoc
rule-metadata.description: Checks to ensure that the following tags exist (if required): @return, @param, @throws or @exception, @see or {@inheritDoc}.

property-metadata.name: scope
property-metadata.description: Visibility scope where Javadoc comments are checked.

property-metadata.name: excludeScope
property-metadata.description: visibility scope where Javadoc comments are not checked

property-metadata.name: allowUndeclaredRTE
property-metadata.description: Whether to allow documented exceptions that are not declared if they are a subclass of java.lang.RuntimeException.

property-metadata.name: allowThrowsTagsForSubclasses
property-metadata.description: Whether to allow documented exceptions that are subclass of one of declared exception.

property-metadata.name: allowMissingParamTags
property-metadata.description: Whether to ignore errors when a method has parameters but does not have matching param tags in the javadoc.

property-metadata.name: allowMissingThrowsTags
property-metadata.description: Whether to ignore errors when a method declares that it throws exceptions but does have matching throws tags in the javadoc.

property-metadata.name: allowMissingReturnTag
property-metadata.description: Whether to ignore errors when a method returns non-void type does have a return tag in the javadoc.

property-metadata.name: allowMissingJavadoc
property-metadata.description: Whether to ignore errors when a method javadoc is missed

property-metadata.name: allowMissingPropertyJavadoc
tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Style Javadoc
rule-metadata.description: Validates Javadoc comments to help ensure they are well formed. The following checks are performed: 1.Ensures the first sentence ends with proper punctuation (That is a period, question mark, or exclamation mark). Javadoc automatically places the first sentence in the method summary table and index. With out proper punctuation the Javadoc may be malformed. 2.Check text for incomplete HTML tags. Verifies that HTML tags have corresponding end tags and issues an "Unclosed HTML tag found:" error if not. An "Extra HTML tag found:" error is issued if an end tag is found without a previous open tag.

property-metadata.name: scope
property-metadata.description: Visibility scope where Javadoc comments are checked.

property-metadata.name: excludeScope
property-metadata.description: visibility scope where Javadoc comments are not checked.

property-metadata.name: checkEmptyJavadoc
property-metadata.description: Whether to check if the Javadoc is missing a describing text.

property-metadata.name: checkFirstSentence
property-metadata.description: Whether to check the first sentence for proper end of sentence.

property-metadata.name: checkHtml
property-metadata.description: Whether to check for incomplete html tags.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Type Javadoc
rule-metadata.description: Checks Javadoc comments for class and interface definitions.

property-metadata.name: excludeScope
property-metadata.description: visibility scope where Javadoc comments are not checked

property-metadata.name: scope
property-metadata.description: Visibility scope where Javadoc comments are checked.

property-metadata.name: authorFormat
property-metadata.description: Pattern for @author tag.

property-metadata.name: versionFormat
property-metadata.description: Pattern for @version tag.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Variable Javadoc
rule-metadata.description: Checks that variables have Javadoc comments.

property-metadata.name: excludeScope
property-metadata.description: visibility scope where Javadoc comments are not checked

property-metadata.name: scope
property-metadata.description: Visibility scope where Javadoc comments are checked.

rule-metadata.name: Abstract Class Name
rule-metadata.description: Checks that abstract class names follow naming convention.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: Regular expression defining required naming pattern.

rule-metadata.name: Constant Names
rule-metadata.description: Checks that constents (static final fields) variables follow naming convention.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: Regular expression defining required naming pattern.

rule-metadata.name: Local Final Variable Names
rule-metadata.description: Checks that local final variables follow naming convention.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: Regular expression defining required naming pattern.

rule-metadata.name: Local Variable Names
rule-metadata.description: Checks that local variables follow naming convention.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: Regular expression defining required naming pattern.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Member Names
rule-metadata.description: Checks that member variables (non-static fields) follow naming convention.

property-metadata.name: applyToPublic
property-metadata.description: Controls whether to apply the check to public member.

property-metadata.name: applyToProtected
property-metadata.description: Controls whether to apply the check to protected member.

property-metadata.name: applyToPackage
property-metadata.description: Controls whether to apply the check to package-protected member.

property-metadata.name: applyToPrivate
property-metadata.description: Controls whether to apply the check to private member.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: Regular expression defining required naming pattern.

rule-metadata.name: Method Names
rule-metadata.description: Checks that method names follow naming convention.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: Regular expression defining required naming pattern.

rule-metadata.name: Package Names
rule-metadata.description: Checks that package names follow naming convention.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: Regular expression defining required naming pattern.

rule-metadata.name: Parameter Names
rule-metadata.description: Checks that parameter names follow naming convention.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: Regular expression defining required naming pattern.

rule-metadata.name: Static Variable Names
rule-metadata.description: Checks that static variables (static, non-final fields) follow naming convention.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: Regular expression defining required naming pattern.

rule-metadata.name: Type Names
rule-metadata.description: Checks that class names follow naming convention.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: Regular expression defining required naming pattern.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Header
rule-metadata.description: Checks that a source file begins with a specified header. Property headerFile specifies a file that contains the required header. Alternatively, the header specification can be set directly in the header property without the need for an external file.

property-metadata.name: headerFile
property-metadata.description: name of the file containing the required header.

property-metadata.name: header
property-metadata.description: the required header specified inline. Individual header lines must be separated by the string "\n" (even on platforms with a different line separator).

property-metadata.name: ignoreLines
property-metadata.description: line numbers to ignore (comma separated)

rule-metadata.name: Regular Expression Header
rule-metadata.description:
Checks the header of a source file against a header that contains a regular expression for each line of the source header.
Rationale: In some projects checking against a fixed header is not sufficient, e.g. the header might require a copyright line where the year information is not static.

property-metadata.name: headerFile
property-metadata.description: name of the file containing the required header.

property-metadata.name: header
property-metadata.description: the required header specified inline. Individual header lines must be separated by the string "\n" (even on platforms with a different line separator), and regular expressions must not span multiple lines.

property-metadata.name: multiLines
property-metadata.description: line numbers to repeat (zero or more times)

rule-metadata.name: Avoid Star (Demand) Imports
rule-metadata.description: Checks for use of demand import statements.

property-metadata.name: excludes
property-metadata.description: packages where star imports are allowed. Note that this property is not recursive, subpackages of excluded packages are not automatically excluded.

rule-metadata.name: Illegal Imports
rule-metadata.description: Checks for imports from a set of illegal packages.

property-metadata.name: illegalPkgs
property-metadata.description: Comma (',') seperated list of illegal packages.

rule-metadata.name: Import Order Check
rule-metadata.description: Checks the ordering/grouping of imports. Ensures that groups of imports come in a specific order (e.g., java. comes first, javax. comes first, then everything else) and imports within each group are in lexicographic order.

property-metadata.name: groups
property-metadata.description: list of imports groups (every group identified by string it's started)

property-metadata.name: ordered
property-metadata.description: whether imports within group should be sorted

property-metadata.name: separated
property-metadata.description: whether imports groups should be separated by, at least, one blank line

property-metadata.name: caseSensitive
property-metadata.description: whether strings comprision should be case sensitive or not

rule-metadata.name: Redundant Imports
rule-metadata.description: Checks for redundant import statements. An import statement is considered redundant if: 1) It is a duplicate of another import. This is, when a class is imported more than once; or 2) The class imported is from the java.lang package, e.g. importing java.lang.String; or 3) The class imported is from the same package.

rule-metadata.name: Unused Imports
rule-metadata.description: Checks for unused import statements.

rule-metadata.name: Anonymous inner classes lengths
rule-metadata.description:
Checks for long anonymous inner classes.
Rationale: If an anonymous inner class becomes very long it is hard to understand and to see the flow of the method where the class is defined. Therefore long anonymous inner classes should usually be refactored into a named inner class. See also Bloch, Effective Java, p. 93.

property-metadata.name: max
property-metadata.description: maximum allowable number of lines.

rule-metadata.name: Executable Statement Size
rule-metadata.description: Restricts the number of executable statements to a specified limit

property-metadata.name: max
property-metadata.description: Maximum allowed parameters.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Maximum File Length
rule-metadata.description: Checks for source files that exceed the configured maximum length.

property-metadata.name: max
property-metadata.description: Maximum number of lines allowed.

rule-metadata.name: Maximum Line Length
rule-metadata.description: Checks for lines that exceed the configured maximum length.

property-metadata.name: ignorePattern
property-metadata.description: Pattern for lines to ignore.

property-metadata.name: max
property-metadata.description: Maximum allowed line length.

property-metadata.name: tabWidth
property-metadata.description: Number of characters to count for each tab character.

rule-metadata.name: Maximum Method Length
rule-metadata.description: Checks for methods that exceed the configured maximum length.

property-metadata.name: max
property-metadata.description: Maximum number of lines allowed.

property-metadata.name: countEmpty
property-metadata.description: whether to count empty lines and single line comments of the form //

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Maximum Parameters
rule-metadata.description: Checks the number of parameters of a method or constructor.

property-metadata.name: max
property-metadata.description: Maximum allowed parameters.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Empty For Initializer Pad

property-metadata.name: option
property-metadata.description: Policy on how to pad an empty for iterator.

rule-metadata.name: Empty For Iterator Pad
rule-metadata.description: Checks the padding of an empty for iterator; that is whether white space is required at an empty for iterator, or such white space is forbidden.

property-metadata.name: option
property-metadata.description: Policy on how to pad an empty for iterator.

rule-metadata.name: No Whitespace After
rule-metadata.description: Checks that there is no whitespace after a token. More specifically, it checks that it is not followed by whitespace, or (if linebreaks are allowed) all characters on the line after are whitespace. To forbid linebreaks after a token, set property allowLineBreaks to false.

property-metadata.name: allowLineBreaks
property-metadata.description: Whether whitespace is allowed if the token is at a linebreak.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: No Whitespace Before
rule-metadata.description: Checks that there is no whitespace before a token. More specifically, it checks that it is not preceded with whitespace, or (if linebreaks are allowed) all characters on the line before are whitespace. To allow linebreaks before a token, set property allowLineBreaks to true.

property-metadata.name: allowLineBreaks
property-metadata.description: Whether whitespace is allowed if the token is at a linebreak.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Operator Wrap
rule-metadata.description: Checks the policy on how to wrap lines on operators.

property-metadata.name: option
property-metadata.description: Policy on how to wrap lines. nl = operator must be on a new line, eol = operator must be at the end of the line.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Method Parameter Pad
rule-metadata.description: Checks the padding between the identifier of a method definition, constructor definition, method call, or constructor invocation; and the left parenthesis of the parameter list. That is, if the identifier and left parenthesis are on the same line, checks whether a space is required immediately after the identifier or such a space is forbidden. If they are not on the same line, reports an error, unless configured to allow line breaks. To allow linebreaks after the identifier, set property allowLineBreaks to true.

property-metadata.name: allowLineBreaks
property-metadata.description: whether a line break between the identifier and left parenthesis is allowed

property-metadata.name: option
property-metadata.description: That is, if the identifier and left parenthesis are on the same line, checks whether a space is required immediately after the identifier or such a space is forbidden

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Paren Pad
rule-metadata.description: Checks the policy on the padding of parentheses; i.e. whether a space is required after a left parenthesis and before a right parenthesis, or such spaces are forbidden.

property-metadata.name: option
property-metadata.description: Policy on how to pad parentheses. nospace = do not pad (e.g. method(a, b)). space = ensure padding (e.g. method( a, b )).

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Tab Character
rule-metadata.description: Checks that there are no tab characters ('\t') in the source code.

rule-metadata.name: Typecast Paren Pad
rule-metadata.description: Checks the policy on the padding of parentheses for typecasts. That is, whether a space is required after a left parenthesis and before a right parenthesis, or such spaces are forbidden.

property-metadata.name: option
property-metadata.description: Policy on how to pad parentheses. nospace = do not pad (e.g. method(a, b)). space = ensure padding (e.g. method( a, b )).

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Whitespace After
rule-metadata.description: Checks that a token is followed by whitespace.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Whitespace Around
rule-metadata.description: Checks that a token is surrounded by whitespace.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Modifier Order
rule-metadata.description: Checks that the order of modifiers conforms to the suggestions in the Java Language specification, sections 8.1.1, 8.3.1 and 8.4.3. The correct order is: public, protected, private, abstract, static, final, transient, volatile, synchronized, native, strictfp.

rule-metadata.name: Redundant Modifier
rule-metadata.description: Checks that method declarations in interfaces include neither the public modifier nor the abstract modifier (see the Java Language specification, section 9.4). Also checks that variable declarations in interfaces include none of the following modifiers: public, static, final (variables in interface definitions are constants and have these modifiers implicitly, see the Java Language specification, section 9.3).

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Avoid Nested Blocks
rule-metadata.description: Finds nested blocks, i.e. blocks that are used freely in the code. Rationale: Nested blocks are often leftovers from the debugging process, they confuse the reader.

property-metadata.name: allowInSwitchCase
property-metadata.description: Allow nested blocks in case statements

rule-metadata.name: Empty Block
rule-metadata.description: Checks for empty blocks.

property-metadata.name: option
property-metadata.description: Policy on block contents. text = require that there is some text in the block. stmt = require that there is a statement in the block.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Blocks to check.

rule-metadata.name: Left Curly Brace Placement
rule-metadata.description: Checks the placement of left curly braces on types, methods and other the other blocks.

property-metadata.name: option
property-metadata.description: Defines where left curly braces should be placed. 'eol' = End-of-Line, 'nl' = New-Line, and 'nlow' = New-Line-on-Wrap (if the brace will fit on the first line of the statement, taking into account maximum line length, then apply eol rule, otherwise apply the nl rule).

property-metadata.name: maxLineLength
property-metadata.description: Line length for applying wrap rule.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Blocks to check.

rule-metadata.name: Need Braces
rule-metadata.description: Checks for braces around code blocks.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Blocks to check.

rule-metadata.name: Right Curly Brace Placement
rule-metadata.description: Checks the placement of right curly braces ('}') for else, try, and catch tokens.

property-metadata.name: option
property-metadata.description: Defines where right curly braces should be placed. same = brace must be on the same line as the next statement. alone = brace must be alone on the line.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Blocks to check.

rule-metadata.name: Avoid Inline Conditionals
rule-metadata.description: Detects inline conditionals. Rationale: Some developers find inline conditionals hard to read, so their company's coding standards forbids them.

rule-metadata.name: Covariant Equals
rule-metadata.description:
Checks that classes that define a covariant equals() method also override method equals(java.lang.Object). Inspired by findbugs.
Rationale: Mistakenly defining a covariant equals() method without overriding method equals(java.lang.Object) can produce unexpected runtime behaviour.

rule-metadata.name: Default Comes Last
rule-metadata.description:
Check that the default is after all the cases in a switch statement.
Rationale: Java allows default anywhere within the switch statement. But it is more readable if it comes after the last case

rule-metadata.name: Declaration Order Check
rule-metadata.description:
According to Code Conventions for the Java Programming Language , the parts of a class or interface declaration should appear in the following order
Class (static) variables. First the public class variables, then the protected, then package level (no access modifier), and then the private. Instance variables. First the public class variables, then the protected, then package level (no access modifier), and then the private. Constructors Methods

rule-metadata.name: Double Checked Locking
rule-metadata.description: The "double-checked locking" idiom (DCL) tries to avoid the runtime cost of synchronization. The problem with the DCL idiom in Java is that it just does not work correctly. Using it introduces bugs that are extremely hard to track down and reproduce.

rule-metadata.name: Empty Statement
rule-metadata.description: Detects empty statements (standalone ;).

rule-metadata.name: Equals and HashCode
rule-metadata.description: Checks that classes that override equals() also override hashCode().

rule-metadata.name: Explicit Initialization
rule-metadata.description:
Checks if any class or object member explicitly initialized to default for its type value (null for object references, zero for numeric types and char and false for booolean.
Rationale: each instance variable gets initialized twice, to the same value. Java initializes each instance variable to its default value (0 or null) before performing any initialization specified in the code. So in this case, x gets initialized to 0 twice, and bar gets initialized to null twice. So there is a minor inefficiency. This style of coding is a hold-over from C/C++ style coding, and it shows that the developer isn't really confident that Java really initializes instance variables to default values.

rule-metadata.name: Fall Through
rule-metadata.description:
Checks for fall through in switch statements Finds locations where a case contains Java code - but lacks a break, return, throw or continue statement.
Note: the check works in assumption that there is no unreachable code in the case.

rule-metadata.name: Final Local Variable
rule-metadata.description: Checks that local variables that never have their values changed are declared final. The check can be configured to also check that unchanged parameters are declared final.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Hidden Field
rule-metadata.description: Checks that a local variable or a parameter does not shadow a field that is defined in the same class.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

property-metadata.name: ignoreFormat
property-metadata.description: pattern for names to ignore

property-metadata.name: ignoreConstructorParameter
property-metadata.description: Controls whether to ignore constructor parameters.

property-metadata.name: ignoreSetter
property-metadata.description: Controls whether to ignore the parameter of a property setter method, where the property setter method for field "xyz" has name "setXyz", one parameter named "xyz", and return type void.

rule-metadata.name: Illegal Instantiation
rule-metadata.description: Checks for illegal instantiations where a factory method is preferred. Rationale: Depending on the project, for some classes it might be preferable to create instances through factory methods rather than calling the constructor. A simple example is the java.lang.Boolean class. In order to save memory and CPU cycles, it is preferable to use the predefined constants TRUE and FALSE. Constructor invocations should be replaced by calls to Boolean.valueOf(). Some extremely performance sensitive projects may require the use of factory methods for other classes as well, to enforce the usage of number caches or object pools.

property-metadata.name: classes
property-metadata.description: Comman seperated list of classes that should not be instantiated.

rule-metadata.name: Illiegal Catch
rule-metadata.description:
Catching java.lang.Exception, java.lang.Error or java.lang.RuntimeException is almost never acceptable.
Rationale: Junior developers often simply catch Exception in an attempt to handle multiple exception classes. This unfortunately leads to code that inadvertantly catchs NPE, OutOfMemoryErrors, etc.

property-metadata.name: illegalClassNames
property-metadata.description: exception class names to reject

rule-metadata.name: Illegal Tokens
rule-metadata.description:
Checks for illegal tokens.
Rational: Certain language features often lead to hard to maintain code or are non-obvious to novice developers. Other features may be discouraged in certain frameworks, such as not having native methods in EJB components.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Illegal Tokens Text
rule-metadata.description: Checks for illegal token text.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: illegal pattern

property-metadata.name: ignoreCase
property-metadata.description: Controls whether to ignore case when matching.

property-metadata.name: message
property-metadata.description: Message which is used to notify about violations; if empty then the default message is used.

rule-metadata.name: Illegal Type
rule-metadata.description:
Checks that particular class are never used as types in variable declarations, return values or parameters. Includes a pattern check that by default disallows abstract classes.
Rationale: Helps reduce coupling on concrete classes. In addition abstract classes should be thought of a convenience base class implementations of interfaces and as such are not types themsleves.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

property-metadata.name: illegalClassNames
property-metadata.default-value: java.util.GregorianCalendar, java.util.Hashtable, java.util.HashSet, java.util.HashMap, java.util.ArrayList, java.util.LinkedList, java.util.LinkedHashMap, java.util.LinkedHashSet, java.util.TreeSet, java.util.TreeMap, java.util.Vector
property-metadata.description: classes that should not be used as types in variable declarations, return values or parameters.

property-metadata.name: ignoredMethodNames
property-metadata.description: methods that should not be checked.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: pattern for illegal class name

rule-metadata.name: Inner Assignment
rule-metadata.description: Checks for assignments in subexpressions, such as in "String s = Integer.toString(i = 2);". Rationale: With the exception of for iterators, all assignments should occur in their own toplevel statement to increase readability. With inner assignments like the above it is difficult to see all places where a variable is set.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Junit Test Case
rule-metadata.description:
Ensures that the setUp(), tearDown()methods are named correctly, have no arguments, return void and are either public or protected. Also ensures that suite() is named correctly, have no arguments, return junit.framewotk.Test, public and static.
Rationale: often times developers will misname one or more of these methods and not realise that the method is not being called.

rule-metadata.name: Magic Number
rule-metadata.description: Checks that there are no "magic numbers", where a magic number is a numeric literal that is not defined as a constant.

property-metadata.name: ignoreNumbers
property-metadata.description: Comman seperated list of non-Magic numbers.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Missing Constructor
rule-metadata.description: Checks that classes (except abtract one) define a ctor and don't rely on the default one.

rule-metadata.name: Missing Switch Default
rule-metadata.description: Checks that switch statement has "default" clause. Rationale: It's usually a good idea to introduce a default case in every switch statement. Even if the developer is sure that all currently possible cases are covered, this should be expressed in the default branch, e.g. by using an assertion. This way the code is protected aginst later changes, e.g. introduction of new types in an enumeration type.

rule-metadata.name: Modified Control Variable
Multiple String Literals
rule-metadata.description:
Checks for multiple occurrences of the same string literal within a single file.
Rationale: Code duplication makes maintenance more difficult, so it can be better to replace the multiple occurrences with a constant.

property-metadata.name: allowedDuplicates
property-metadata.description: The maximum number of occurences to allow without generating a warning

rule-metadata.name: Multiple Variable Declaration
rule-metadata.description:
Checks that each variable declaration is in its own statement and on its own line.
Rationale: the SUN Code conventions chapter 6.1 recommends that declarations should be one per line/statement

rule-metadata.name: Nested If Depth
rule-metadata.description: Restricts nested if-else blocks to a specified depth (default = 1).

property-metadata.name: max
property-metadata.description: allowed nesting depth

rule-metadata.name: Nested Try Depth
rule-metadata.description: Restricts nested try-catch blocks to a specified depth (default = 1).

property-metadata.name: max
property-metadata.description: allowed nesting depth

rule-metadata.name: Package Declaration
rule-metadata.description:
Ensure a class is has a package declaration.
Rationale: Classes that live in the null package cannot be imported. Many novice developers are not aware of this.

rule-metadata.name: Parameter Assignment
rule-metadata.description:
Disallow assignment of parameters.
Rationale: Parameter assignment is often considered poor programming practice. Forcing developers to declare parameters as final is often onerous. Having a check ensure that parameters are never assigned would give the best of both worlds.

rule-metadata.name: Redundant Throws
rule-metadata.description: Checks for redundant exceptions declared in throws clause such as duplicates, unchecked exceptions or subclasses of another declared exception.

property-metadata.name: allowUnchecked
property-metadata.description: Whether unchecked exceptions in throws are allowed or not.

property-metadata.name: allowSubclasses
property-metadata.description: Whether subclass of another declared exception is allowed in throws clause.

rule-metadata.name: Require This
rule-metadata.description: Checks that code doesn't rely on the "this." default, i.e. references to instance variables and methods of the present object are explicitly of the form "this.varName" or "this.methodName(args)".

property-metadata.name: checkFields
property-metadata.description: whether we should check fields usage or not

property-metadata.name: checkMethods
property-metadata.description: whether we should check methods usage or not

rule-metadata.name: Return Count
rule-metadata.description:
Restrict the number of return statements. Default = 2.
Rationale: Too many return points can be indication that code is attempting to do too much or may be difficult to understand.

property-metadata.name: max
property-metadata.description: maximum allowed number of return statments

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: method names to ignore

rule-metadata.name: Simplify Boolean Expression
rule-metadata.description: Checks for overly complicated boolean expressions. Currently finds code like if (b == true), b || true, !false, etc.

rule-metadata.name: Simplify Boolean Return
rule-metadata.description: Checks for overly complicated boolean return statements.

rule-metadata.name: String Literal Equality
rule-metadata.description:
Checks that string literals are not used with == or !=.
Rationale: Novice Java programmers often use code like if (x == "something") when they mean if ("something".equals(x)).

rule-metadata.name: SuperClone
rule-metadata.description: Checks that an overriding clone() method invokes super.clone().

rule-metadata.name: SuperFinalize
rule-metadata.description: Checks that an overriding finalize() method invokes super.finalize().

rule-metadata.name: Trailing Array Comma
Unnecessary Parentheses
rule-metadata.description: Checks for the use of unnecessary parentheses.

rule-metadata.name: Design For Extension
rule-metadata.description: Checks that classes are designed for extension. More specifically, it enforces a programming style where superclasses provide empty "hooks" that can be implemented by subclasses. The exact rule is that nonprivate, nonstatic methods of classes that can be subclassed must either be a) abstract or b) final or c) have an empty implementation. Rationale: This API design style protects superclasses against beeing broken by subclasses. The downside is that subclasses are limited in their flexibility, in particular they cannot prevent execution of code in the superclass, but that also means that subclasses cannot corrupt the state of the superclass by forgetting to call the super method.

rule-metadata.name: Final Class
rule-metadata.description: Checks that a class which has only private constructors is declared as final.

rule-metadata.name: Hide Utility Class Constructor
rule-metadata.description: Make sure that utility classes (classes that contain only static methods) do not have a public constructor. Rationale: Instantiating utility classes does not make sense. Hence the constructors should either be private or (if you want to allow subclassing) protected. A common mistake is forgetting to hide the default constructor.

rule-metadata.name: Interface Is Type
rule-metadata.description: Implements Bloch, Effective Java, Item 17 - Use Interfaces only to define types. According to Bloch, an interface should describe a type. It is therefore inappropriate to define an interface that does not contain any methods but only constants. The Standard class javax.swing.SwingConstants is an example of a class that would be flagged by this check.

property-metadata.name: allowMarkerInterfaces
property-metadata.description: Controls whether marker interfaces like Serializable are allowed.

rule-metadata.name: Mutable Exception
rule-metadata.description:
Ensures that exceptions (defined as any class name conforming to some regular expression) are immutable. That is, have only final fields.
The current algorithm is very simple it checks that all members of exception are final. User can still mutates an exception's instance (e.g. Throwable has setStackTrace(StackTraceElement[] stackTrace) method which changes stack trace). But, at least, all information provided by this exception type is unchangable.
Rationale: Exception instances should represent an error condition. Having non final fields not only allows the state to be modified by accident and therefore mask the original condition but also allows developers to accidentally forget to initialise state thereby leading to code catching the exception to draw incorrect conclusions based on the state.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: pattern for name of exception class.

rule-metadata.name: Throws Count
rule-metadata.description:
Restricts throws statements to a specified count (default = 1).
Rationale: Exceptions form part of a methods interface. Declaring a method to throw too many differently rooted exceptions makes exception handling onerous and leads to poor programming practices such as catch (Exception). This check forces developers to put exceptions into a heirachy such that in the simplest case, only one type of exception need be checked for by a caller but allows any sub-classes to be caught specifically if necessary.

property-metadata.name: max
property-metadata.description: maximum allowed number of throws statments

rule-metadata.name: Visibility Modifier
rule-metadata.description: Checks visibility of class members. Only static final members may be public; other class members must be private unless property protectedAllowed or packageAllowed is set.

property-metadata.name: packageAllowed
property-metadata.description: Whether package visible members are allowed or not.

property-metadata.name: protectedAllowed
property-metadata.description: Whether protected members are allowed or not.

property-metadata.name: publicMemberPattern
property-metadata.description: Pattern for public members that should be ignored.

rule-metadata.name: Strict Duplicate Code
rule-metadata.description: There are many trade-offs when writing a duplicate code detection tool. Some of the conflicting goals are: Fast Low memory usage Avoid false alarms Support multiple/arbitrary languages Support Fuzzy matches (comments, whitespace, linebreaks, variable renaming, etc.)

property-metadata.name: min
property-metadata.description: how many lines must be equal to be considered a duplicate

property-metadata.name: charset
property-metadata.description: name of the file charset

rule-metadata.name: Boolean Expression Complexity
rule-metadata.description: Restrict the number of number of &&, || and ^ in an expression. Rationale: Too many conditions leads to code that is difficult to read and hence debug and maintain.

property-metadata.name: max
property-metadata.description: the maximum allowed number of boolean operations in one experession.

rule-metadata.name: Class Data Abstraction Coupling
rule-metadata.description: This metric measures the number of instantiations of other classes within the given class. This type of coupling is not caused by inheritance or the object oriented paradigm. Generally speaking, any abstract data type with other abstract data types as members has data abstraction coupling; therefore, if a class has a local variable that is an instantiation (object) of another class, there is data abstraction coupling. The higher the DAC, the more complex the data structure (classes) of the system.

property-metadata.name: max
property-metadata.description: the maximum threshold allowed

rule-metadata.name: Class Fan Out Complexity
rule-metadata.description: The number of other classes a given class relies on. Also the square of this has been shown to indicate the amount of maintenence required in functional programs (on a file basis) at least.

property-metadata.name: max
property-metadata.description: the maximum threshold allowed

rule-metadata.name: Cyclomatic Complexity
rule-metadata.description: Checks cyclomatic complexity against a specified limit. The complexity is measured by the number of if, while, do, for, ?:, catch, switch, case statements, and operators && and || (plus one) in the body of a constructor, method, static initializer, or instance initializer. It is a measure of the minimum number of possible paths through the source and therefore the number of required tests. Generally 1-4 is considered good, 5-7 ok, 8-10 consider re-factoring, and 11+ re-factor now!

property-metadata.name: max
property-metadata.description: the maximum threshold allowed

rule-metadata.name: Non Commenting Source Statements
rule-metadata.description: Determines complexity of methods, classes and files by counting the Non Commenting Source Statements (NCSS). This check adheres to the specification for the JavaNCSS-Tool written by Chr. Clemens Lee which sadly seems to have been pulled off the web. Rougly said the NCSS metric is calculated by counting the source lines which are not comments, (nearly) equivalent to counting the semicolons and opening curly braces. The NCSS for a class is summarized from the NCSS of all its methods, the NCSS of its nested classes and the number of member variable declarations. The NCSS for a file is summarized from the ncss of all its top level classes, the number of imports and the package declaration. Rationale: Too large methods and classes are hard to read and costly to maintain. A large NCSS number often means that a method or class has too many responsabilities and/or functionalities which should be decomposed into smaller units.

property-metadata.name: methodMaximum
property-metadata.description: the maximum allowed number of non commenting lines in a method.

property-metadata.name: classMaximum
property-metadata.description: the maximum allowed number of non commenting lines in a class.

property-metadata.name: fileMaximum
property-metadata.description: the maximum allowed number of non commenting lines in a file.

rule-metadata.name: NPath Complexity
rule-metadata.description:
The NPATH metric computes the number of possible execution paths through a function. It takes into account the nesting of conditional statements and multi-part boolean expressions (e.g., A && B, C || D, etc.).
Rationale: Nejmeh says that his group had an informal NPATH limit of 200 on individual routines; functions that exceeded this value were candidates for further decomposition - or at least a closer look mp;& and || (plus one) in the body of a constructor, method, static initializer, or instance initializer. It is a measure of the minimum number of possible paths through the source and therefore the number of required tests. Generally 1-4 is considered good, 5-7 ok, 8-10 consider re-factoring, and 11+ re-factor now!

property-metadata.name: max
property-metadata.description: the maximum threshold allowed

rule-metadata.name: Array Type Style
rule-metadata.description: Checks the style of array type definitions. Some like Java-style: public static void main(String[] args) and some like C-style: public static void main(String args[]).

property-metadata.name: javaStyle
property-metadata.description: Controls whether to enforce Java style (true) or C style (false).

rule-metadata.name: Descendent Token Check
rule-metadata.description:
Checks for restricted tokens beneath other tokens.
WARNING: This is a very powerful and flexible check, but, at the same time, it is low level and very implementation dependent because its results depend on the grammar we use to build abstract syntax trees. Thus we recomend using other checks when they provide the desired funcionality. All in all, this check just works on the level of an abstract tree and knows nothing about language structures.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

property-metadata.name: limitedTokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

property-metadata.name: minimumDepth
property-metadata.description: the mimimum depth for descendant counts

property-metadata.name: maximumDepth
property-metadata.description: the maximum depth for descendant counts

property-metadata.name: minimumNumber
property-metadata.description: a minimum count for descendants

property-metadata.name: maximumNumber
property-metadata.description: a maximum count for descendants

property-metadata.name: minimumMessage
property-metadata.description: error message when minimum count not reached

property-metadata.name: maximumMessage
property-metadata.description: error message when maximum count exceeded

rule-metadata.name: Final Parameters
rule-metadata.description: Check that method/constructor parameters are final. Interface methods are not checked - the final keyword does not make sense for interface method parameters as there is no code that could modify the parameter. Rationale: Changing the value of parameters during the execution of the method's algorithm can be confusing and should be avoided. A great way to let the Java compiler prevent this coding style is to declare parameters final.

property-metadata.name: tokens
property-metadata.description: Tokens to check.

rule-metadata.name: Generic Illegal Regexp
rule-metadata.description: A generic check for code problems - the user can search for any pattern. For example: exception.printStacktrace(), System.out.println(), System.exit(), etc.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: Pattern to check for.

property-metadata.name: ignoreCase
property-metadata.description: Controls whether to ignore case when searching.

property-metadata.name: ignoreComments
property-metadata.description: Controls whether to ignore text in comments when searching.

property-metadata.name: message
property-metadata.description: Message which is used to notify about violations, if empty then default(hard-coded) message is used.

rule-metadata.name: Indentation
rule-metadata.description:
Checks correct indentation of Java Code.
The basic idea behind this is that while pretty printers are sometimes convienent for bulk reformats of legacy code, they often either aren't configurable enough or just can't anticipate how format should be done. Sometimes this is personal preference, other times it is practical experience. In any case, this check should just ensure that a minimal set of indentation rules are followed.

property-metadata.name: basicOffset
property-metadata.description: how many spaces to use for new indentation level

property-metadata.name: braceAdjustment
property-metadata.description: how far brace should be indented when on next line

property-metadata.name: caseIndent
property-metadata.description: how much to indent a case label

rule-metadata.name: New Line At End Of File
rule-metadata.description:
Checks whether files end with a new line.
Rationale: Any source files and text files in general should end with a newline character, especially when using SCM systems such as CVS. CVS will even print a warning when it encounters a file that doesn't end with a newline.

property-metadata.name: lineSeparator
property-metadata.description: type of line separator

property-metadata.name: fileExtensions
property-metadata.description: file type extension of the files to check.

rule-metadata.name: Required Regular Expression
rule-metadata.description: A check that makes sure that a specified pattern exists in the code, e.g. a required legal text. It does not care about where in the file the pattern is

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: required pattern

rule-metadata.name: Todo Comment
rule-metadata.description: A check for TODO: comments. Actually it is a generic regular expression matcher on Java comments. To check for other patterns in Java comments, set property format.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: Regular expression definging pattern to look for.

rule-metadata.name: Translation
rule-metadata.description: A FileSetCheck that ensures the correct translation of code by checking property files for consistency regarding their keys. Two property files describing one and the same context are consistent if they contain the same keys.

property-metadata.name: fileExtensions
property-metadata.description: file type extension to identify translation files. Setting this property is typically only required if your translation files are preprocessed and the original files do not have the extension .properties

rule-metadata.name: Trailing Comment
rule-metadata.description:
The check to ensure that requires that comments be the only thing on a line. For the case of // comments that means that the only thing that should precede it is whitespace. It doesn't check comments if they do not end line, i.e. it accept the following: Thread.sleep( 10 <some comment here> ); Format property is intended to deal with the "} // while" example.
Rationale: Steve McConnel in "Code Complete" suggests that endline comments are a bad practice. An end line comment would be one that is on the same line as actual code. For example:
a = b + c; // Some insightful comment d = e / f; // Another comment for this line
Quoting "Code Complete" for the justfication: "The comments have to be aligned so that they do not interfere with the visual structure of the code. If you don't align them neatly, they'll make your listing look like it's been through a washing machine." "Endline comments tend to be hard to format...It takes time to align them. Such time is not spent learning more about the code; it's dedicated solely to the tedious task of pressing the spacebar or tab key." "Endline comments are also hard to maintain. If the code on any line containing an endline comment grows, it bumps the comment farther out, and all the other endline comments will have to bumped out to match. Styles that are hard to maintain aren't maintained...." "Endline comments also tend to be cryptic. The right side of the line doesn't offer much room and the desire to keep the comment on one line means the comment must be short. Work then goes into making the line as short as possible instead of as clear as possible. The comment usually ends up as cryptic as possible...." "A systemic problem with endline comments is that it's hard to write a meaningful comment for one line of code. Most endline comments just repeat the line of code, which hurts more than it helps." His comments on being hard to maintain when the size of the line changes are even more important in the age of automated refactorings.

property-metadata.name: format
property-metadata.description: pattern for string allowed before comment.

rule-metadata.name: Uncommented Main
rule-metadata.description:
Checks for uncommented main() methods (debugging leftovers).
Rationale: main() method can be often used for debug puposes. Thus most of main() method should be removed/commented out of the sources.

property-metadata.name: excludedClasses
property-metadata.description: pattern for qualified names of classes which ar allowed to have main method.

rule-metadata.name: Upper Ell
rule-metadata.description: Checks that long constants are defined with an upper ell. That is ' L' and not 'l'. This is in accordance to the Java Language Specification, Section 3.10.1. Rationale: The lower case letter l looks a lot like the digit 1.

rule-metadata.name: Entity Bean
rule-metadata.description: Checks that a direct entity bean, i.e. a class that directly implements javax.ejb.EntityBean, satisfies these class requirements: - The class is defined as public. - The class cannot be defined as final. - It contains a public constructor with no parameters. - It must not define the finalize method.

property-metadata.name: persistence
property-metadata.description: This property represents the policy for checking entity beans according to whether the beans have bean-managed persistence, container-managed persistence, or mixed persistence.

rule-metadata.name: Final Static
rule-metadata.description:
Checks that all static fields are declared final.
Rational: This check ensures consistent runtime semantics so that EJB containers have the flexibility to distribute instances across multiple JVMs.

rule-metadata.name: Local Home Interface
rule-metadata.description:
Checks that a direct local home interface, i.e. an interface that directly extends javax.ejb.EJBLocalHome, satisfies these requirements:
- The return type of all create<METHOD>(...) methods is not void, because the return type must be the bean's local interface. - The throws clause of all create<METHOD>(...) methods defines the javax.ejb.CreateException. - The throws clause of all methods does not define the java.rmi.RemoteException.
Reference: Enterprise JavaBeansTM Specification,Version 2.0, sections 6.4 and 9.6.

rule-metadata.name: Local Interface
rule-metadata.description:
Checks that a direct local interface, i.e. an interface that directly extends javax.ejb.EJBLocalObject, satisfies these requirements:
- The throws clause of all methods does not define the java.rmi.RemoteException.
Reference: Enterprise JavaBeansTM Specification,Version 2.0, section 9.10.

rule-metadata.name: Message Bean
rule-metadata.description:
Checks that a direct message bean, i.e. a class that directly implements javax.ejb.MessageDrivenBean and javax.jms.MessageListener, satisfies these class requirements:
- The class is defined as public. - The class cannot be defined as final. - The class cannot be defined as abstract. - It contains a public constructor with no parameters. - It must not define the finalize method. - It defines an ejbCreate() method this is public, not final, not static, has no parameters, and has return type void.
Reference: Enterprise JavaBeans™ Specification,Version 2.0, section 15.7.

rule-metadata.name: Remote Home Interface
rule-metadata.description:
Checks that a direct remote home interface, i.e. an interface that directly extends javax.ejb.EJBHome, satisfies these requirements:
- The return type of all create<METHOD>(...) methods is not void, because the return type must be the bean's remote interface. - The throws clause of all create<METHOD>(...) methods defines the javax.ejb.CreateException. - The throws clause of all methods defines the java.rmi.RemoteException.
Reference: Enterprise JavaBeansTM Specification,Version 2.0, sections 6.3 and 9.5.

rule-metadata.name: Remote Interface
rule-metadata.description:
Checks that a direct remote interface, i.e. an interface that directly extends javax.ejb.EJBObject, satisfies these requirements:
- The throws clause of all methods defines the java.rmi.RemoteException.
Reference: Enterprise JavaBeansTM Specification,Version 2.0, section 9.9.

rule-metadata.name: Session Bean
rule-metadata.description:
Checks that a direct session bean, i.e. a class that directly implements javax.ejb.SessionBean, satisfies these class requirements:
- The class is defined as public. - The class cannot be defined as final. - The class cannot be defined as abstract. - It contains a public constructor with no parameters. - It must not define the finalize method. - It defines an ejbCreate<METHOD>() method this is public, not final, not static, and has return type void.
Reference: Enterprise JavaBeans™ Specification,Version 2.0, section 7.10.

rule-metadata.name: This Parameter
rule-metadata.description: Checks that this is not a parameter of any method calls or constructors for a bean. Instead, you must use the result of the getEJBObject() available in SessionContext or EntityContext.

rule-metadata.name: This Return
rule-metadata.description: Checks that this is not returned by a bean method. Instead, you must use the result of the getEJBObject() available in SessionContext or EntityContext.

rule-metadata.name: One Method Private Field
rule-metadata.description:
Checks that a private field is used in more than one method, constructor, or initializer.
Rationale: a private field used in only one method, constructor, or initializer should be replaced by a local variable.

property-metadata.name: ignoreFormat
property-metadata.description: pattern for field names that should be ignored

rule-metadata.name: Unused Local Variable
rule-metadata.description: Checks that a local variable is used after its declaration

property-metadata.name: ignoreFormat
property-metadata.description: pattern for field names that should be ignored

rule-metadata.name: Unused Parameter
rule-metadata.description: Checks that a parameter is used.

property-metadata.name: ignoreFormat
property-metadata.description: pattern for field names that should be ignored

property-metadata.name: ignoreCatch
property-metadata.description: controls whether catch parameters should be ignored

property-metadata.name: ignoreNonLocal
property-metadata.description: controls whether parameters of non local (public, protected or package) methods should be ignored

rule-metadata.name: Unused Private Field
rule-metadata.description: Checks that a private field is used.

property-metadata.name: ignoreFormat
property-metadata.description: pattern for field names that should be ignored

rule-metadata.name: Unused Private Method
rule-metadata.description: Checks that a private method is used.

property-metadata.name: ignoreFormat
property-metadata.description: pattern for field names that should be ignored

property-metadata.name: allowSerializationMethods
property-metadata.description: whether the check should allow serialization-related methods (readObject(), writeObject(), readResolve() and writeReplace())

rule-metadata.name: Severity Match Filter
rule-metadata.description: Filter SeverityMatchFilter decides audit events according to the severity level of the event.

property-metadata.name: severity
property-metadata.description: the severity level of this filter.

property-metadata.name: acceptOnMatch
property-metadata.description: If acceptOnMatch is true, then the filter accepts an audit event if and only if there is a match between the event's severity level and property severity. If acceptOnMatch is false, then the filter accepts an audit event if and only if there is not a match between the event's severity level and property severity.

rule-metadata.name: Suppression Filter
rule-metadata.description: Filter SuppressionFilter rejects audit events for Check errors according to a suppressions XML document in a file. If there is no configured suppressions file, the Filter accepts all audit events.

property-metadata.name: file
property-metadata.description: the name of the suppressions XML document file.

rule-metadata.name: Suppression Comment Filter
rule-metadata.description:
Filter SuppressionCommentFilter uses pairs of comments to suppress audit events.
Rationale: Sometimes there are legitimate reasons for violating a check. When this is a matter of the code in question and not personal preference, the best place to override the policy is in the code itself. Semi-structured comments can be associated with the check. This is sometimes superior to a separate suppressions file, which must be kept up-to-date as the source file is edited.
Usage: This filter only works in conjunction with a FileContentsHolder, since that check makes the suppression comments in the .java files available sub rosa. A configuration that includes this filter must configure FileContentsHolder as a child module of TreeWalker.

property-metadata.name: offCommentFormat
property-metadata.description: comment pattern to trigger filter to begin suppression.

property-metadata.name: onCommentFormat
property-metadata.description: comment pattern to trigger filter to end suppression.

property-metadata.name: checkFormat
property-metadata.description: check pattern to suppress.

property-metadata.name: messageFormat
property-metadata.description: message pattern to suppress.

property-metadata.name: checkCPP
property-metadata.description: whether to check C++ style comments (//)

property-metadata.name: checkC
property-metadata.description: whether to check C style comments (/* ... */)

rule-metadata.name: Checker
rule-metadata.description: Root module of every checkstyle configuration. Cannot be deleted.

property-metadata.name: localeCountry
property-metadata.description: locale country for messages

property-metadata.name: localeLanguage
property-metadata.description: locale language for messages

rule-metadata.name: TreeWalker
rule-metadata.description: FileSetCheck TreeWalker checks individual Java source files and defines properties that are applicable to checking such files.

property-metadata.name: cacheFile
property-metadata.description: caches information about files that have checked ok; used to avoid repeated checks of the same files

property-metadata.name: tabWidth
property-metadata.description: number of expanded spaces for a tab character ('\t'); used in messages and Checks that require a tab width, such as LineLength

property-metadata.name: fileExtensions
property-metadata.description: file type extension to identify java files. Setting this property is typically only required if your java source code is preprocessed before compilation and the original files do not have the extension .java

property-metadata.name: charset
property-metadata.description: name of the file charset
